chapter.htmlHeader: Hearing loss in adults - management in primary care
chapter.summary: Covers the management of a patient in primary care who does not require referral.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with hearing loss in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If the person presents for the first time with hearing loss and there are no indications for referral to ENT or the emergency department:

  • Exclude/treat causes of hearing loss such as impacted wax, acute ear infection (such as otitis externa or media) and middle ear effusion due to acute upper respiratory tract infection (such as a cold or sinusitis).
    • For more information, see the CKS topics on Earwax, Otitis externa, Otitis media - acute and Otitis media with effusion.
      • Wax removal may be an urgent requirement to allow full examination and avoid delay in treatment of underlying pathology.
    • Discuss with/refer to ENT (considering the need for immediate or urgent referral), if after initial treatment for earwax or acute infection:
      • The eardrum cannot be fully examined because of partial or complete obstruction of ear canal.
      • Pain in or around the ear persists for more than one week and has not responded to first line treatment.
      • Discharge (other than wax) from either ear has not resolved with treatment or is recurrent.
      • Abnormalities of the outer ear or eardrum (such as inflammation, eardrum perforation, abnormal bony or skin growths, swelling of the outer ear or blood in the canal) are visible.
      • A middle ear effusion which is not associated with (or persists after) upper respiratory tract infection is suspected.
    • Arrange an audiological assessment:
      • If sensorineural hearing loss is confirmed and no underlying cause requiring further investigation by ENT suspected, hearing aids will be considered.
      • If hearing aids are fitted, face to face follow up (after 6–12 weeks) should be arranged by audiology.
        • Bilateral hearing aids should be offered to people with aidable hearing loss in both ears as this can improve sound quality and make speech easier to understand against background noise.
      • If assistive listening devices or communication strategies are preferred to hearing aids, review should be arranged to assess effectiveness.
      • If hearing loss does not improve with hearing aids – discuss with/refer to ENT.
  • Provide information and support
    • Provide the person (and their family/carers) with information on the cause of hearing loss and management (including use of hearing aids and assistive listening devices [such as personal loops, smoke alarms and doorbell sensors] where appropriate). Patient information on hearing loss is available from:
      • The NHS "Hearing loss."
      • Action on Hearing Loss "Hearing health - factsheets and leaflets on hearing problems."
      • Age UK "Hearing loss."
    • Advise the person on measures to facilitate good hearing, including:
      • Reducing competing noises (such as the radio or TV).
      • Improving the acoustics of the environment, for example, soft furnishings can improve sound quality if a hearing aid is used.
      • Ensuring that lighting is adequate and seating arranged so that people’s faces can be seen as this may help with communication and lipreading.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of hearing loss in primary care are based on the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Hearing loss in adults: assessment and management [NICE, 2018], guidance from the British Academy of Audiology [British Academy of Audiology, 2016] and expert opinion in review articles [Stachler, 2012; Edmiston, 2013; Phan, 2016; Cunningham, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018; Fishman, 2018; Michels, 2019].

Exclude ear wax, acute ear infection and middle ear effusion
  • NICE guidance on Hearing loss in adults: assessment and management [NICE, 2018] recommends that as part of the workup for adults presenting with hearing loss, causes manageable in primary care such as impacted wax, acute ear infection (such as otitis externa or media) and middle ear effusion due to acute upper respiratory tract infection (such as a cold or sinusitis) should be excluded first.
  • The NICE guideline committee noted that earwax removal may be an urgent requirement in order to exclude this as a cause of hearing loss and avoid delay in treatment of underlying pathology [NICE, 2018].
  • Recommendations on indications for referral to/discussion with ENT after initial treatment for earwax or acute infection are taken from NICE guidance [NICE, 2018].
Referral to audiology
  • Clinical guidance [Action on Hearing Loss, 2015; NICE, 2018] highlights the importance of early intervention for adults with hearing loss as this has been shown to improve communication, quality of life and mental health.
  • On average there is a 10 year delay in people aged 55–74 years seeking help for hearing loss and only a third of adults with self-reported hearing loss have had their hearing tested [NICE, 2018; Michels, 2019].
  • Guidance from NICE recommends that findings on pure tone audiometry (which are usually described as mild, moderate, severe or profound) should not be used in isolation for determination of the need for hearing support as this classification is not a reliable indicator of difficulty experienced with communication in background noise [NICE, 2018].
Hearing aids and assistive listening devices
  • Recommendations on hearing aids and assistive listening devices are based on clinical guidance from NHS England [NHS England, 2017], Action on Hearing Loss [Action on Hearing Loss, 2015], NICE [NICE, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Michels, 2019]. Hearing aids and/or assistive listening devices are the mainstay of treatment for permanent hearing loss. Compared to unassisted people with hearing impairment, those who wear hearing aids have improved ability to communicate, quality of life and reduced risk of depression and social isolation [Action on Hearing Loss, 2015; American Academy of Audiology, 2015; NHS England, 2016; Phan, 2016; NICE, 2018; Michels, 2019].
Support and information
  • The recommendations on provision of support and information are based on clinical guidance [NICE, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Stachler, 2012].
  • The risk of hearing aids being trialled but discontinued can be reduced by providing information and advice on strategies to improve hearing and aftercare to ensure effective use of devices [NICE, 2018].

subChapters.fullItemName: Hearing aids and assistive listening devices
subChapters.htmlHeader: Additional information
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Hearing aids
  • Hearing aids consist of a microphone, a battery-powered amplifier, a receiver, and a means to route amplified sound into the ear canal.
  • As hearing aids cannot improve deficits in frequency, temporal and spatial resolution (which are often associated with age-related and noise induced hearing loss), the person may continue to have some hearing difficulties, even when wearing hearing aids [NICE, 2018].
  • Use of bilateral hearing aids improves intelligibility of speech in background noise, sound localisation, and sound quality. If only one hearing aid is used over time deficits may develop in the unaided ear due to reduced stimulation in that ear [NICE, 2018].
Assistive listening devices (ALDs)
  • ALDs (such as loop systems) can improve hearing in situations with background noise by amplifying sound from a specific source (such as a person speaking or a television) and sending it straight to the ears.
  • Other ADLs (such as doorbell sensors, baby alarms and smoke detectors) alert the person to environmental sounds through flashing lights, vibration or loud sounds [Action on Hearing Loss, 2015; NHS England, 2017]. 
  • Some ALDs may be provided by the NHS, social care services or the fire service — provision varies across the UK and the person should be advised to seek advice from local services.
    • Those in employment may be able to get necessary equipment through Access to Work and students may be supported by the Disabled Student’s Allowance.
    • Other ALDs, such as streamers or apps must be purchased [NICE, 2018].
Implantable devices
  • Implantable devices (such as cochlear implants or bone conducting hearing implants) may be appropriate for people whose sensorineural hearing loss is too severe for hearing aids or where there has been limited benefit from hearing aids — these require referral to ENT for surgical intervention [Action on Hearing Loss, 2015]  [NHS England, 2017; NICE, 2018].
